required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Anxiety and Chronic Postsurgical Pain Following Ambulatory Surgery in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Anxiety and Chronic Postsurgical Pain Following Ambulatory Surgery in Children

brief_summary.textblock: Prospective, monocentric, observationnal study. The primary objective of this study is to identify if presurgical child or/and parental anxiety is predictive of chronic postsurgical pain in abdominal or urologic ambulatory surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
The post surgical pain guidelines recommend to identify predictive factors, especially for vulnerable subjects.
For children, there is few data about predictive factors of postoperative pain after ambulatory surgery.
The objective of this study is to collect preoperative data (preoperative children's anxiety and parental anxiety) and postoperative data (postoperative pain measure: the day of surgery and 3 months after surgery) for children undergoing abdominal ou urologic ambulatory surgery, and to determine if there is a relationship between these data (Odds Ratio)

primary_outcome.description: - For children younger than 12 : mYPAS (the Modified Yale Preoperative Anxiety Scale). If the score is less than 24 : quiet child. If the score is greater than 24 : anxious child - For children older than 12 : anxiety visual analog scale (VAS) From 0 (better) to 10 (worse)
anxiety visual analog scale (VAS) From 0 (better) to 10 (worse). More than 3/10 means "anxious"
for children younger than 6: Evendol scale. From 0 (better) to 15 (worse) for children older than 6: anxiety visual analog scale (VAS) From 0 (better) to 10 (worse).
For all children, score PPMP (Postoperative Pain Measure for Parents) From 0 (better) to 10 (worse)

study_pop.textblock: Children undergoing scheduled abdominal or urologic ambulatory surgery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- child from 3 to 18 years old
- undergoing scheduled urology or abdominal ambulatory surgery
- child and parents speaking French
- affiliation to national health insurance
Exclusion Criteria:
- emergency surgery
- lack of parents consent
- no parental support on surgery day

reference.citation: Rabbitts JA, Fisher E, Rosenbloom BN, Palermo TM. Prevalence and Predictors of Chronic Postsurgical Pain in Children: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis. J Pain. 2017 Jun;18(6):605-614. doi: 10.1016/j.jpain.2017.03.007. Epub 2017 Mar 29. Review.
